Remember this? Students go streaking

Students streak through libraries on first night of exams

  • By Reyna Desai
Dec. 15 5:28 pm
  • 78254 commentshttp%3A%2F%2Freesenews.org%2F2010%2F12%2F15%2Ffollowing-tradition-unc-students-streak-during-exams%2F7825%2FRemember+this%3F+Students+go+streaking2010-12-15+22%3A28%3A12Reyna+Desaihttp%3A%2F%2Freesenews.org%2F%3Fp%3D7825
  • E-mail
  • Print

Do you like this story?

Sources

  • http://gradschool.unc.edu/programs/weiss/interesting_place/history/tradition.html
  • http://www.billkirkpatrick.net/scholarship/streaking/
  • http://ask.yahoo.com/20040903.html

Editor’s note: This story was originally published in Dec. 2010, but in the spirit of final exam season, reesenews decided to bring it back for another go.

CHAPEL HILL
Students show school spirit in many ways. Some like to paint their bodies and cheer for the ESPN cameramen at football games. Others proudly don their raggedy Carolina gear 20 years after they graduate.

But then there is the minority that shows its school spirit by getting naked at midnight during 30-degree weather.

On Dec. 10, 2010, approximately fifty students, some wearing disguises such as bandannas across their faces, started their naked-run from the 8th floor of Davis Library.

They ran down the stairs, stopping at each floor to run through bookshelves, before exiting the building to visit the Frank Porter Graham Student Union next door.

A few minutes later, they clustered in the middle of the Student Union to sing the alma mater while everyone in the vicinity feverishly reached for cell phones to capture this bold display.

These are the “UL-streakers,” named after the Undergraduate Library at UNC-Chapel Hill.

Every semester at midnight on the first day of exams, for as long as students can remember, a gaggle of naked students runs across the two major student libraries wearing nothing but shoes and masks.

In the winter months, you might see a scarf or two.

Hundreds of students start filling the library about half an hour before midnight, abandoning their studying to witness this Tar Heel tradition that usually lasts no more than 20 minutes.

After finishing singing the Alma mater and cheering loudly, the group headed to the UL where they finished their nocturnal escapades. There were so many students in the library that many stood on computer tables so that they could catch a glimpse of this notorious tradition.

After singing the Alma mater once again, the exhilarated students rushed back to the 8th floor of Davis Library to throw on their left-behind clothes. They were pink-cheeked — pun intended — and gasping for breath after their long run in the bitterly cold weather.

But bright smiles and excited chatter filled the room as people bonded over their adventures. There’s no embarrassment or awkward sexual tension. Modesty had been long ignored, replaced by camaraderie.

A website made by former UNC-CH professors and graduate students states that the earliest record of streaking at the school was in 1974.

According to the website, The Ultimate North Carolina Quiz Book, states:

“On March 5, more than two hundred male students stripped bare and raced across the campus and through the undergraduate library. Twenty women from Joyner Dormitory joined in. Two days later, to accompaniment by the university’s pep band, more than nine hundred naked students ran single-file through an appreciative crowd before posing for a group photo near South Building. Streaking quickly spread to campuses across the nation before the fad abruptly expired.”

The dozens of students that streak twice a year proves the trend still persists. These streakers may not have a political agenda like many did in 1974, but they believe their reasons are still valuable.

Since streaking is technically against the law — in the United States, a convicted streaker can be cited with a “public nudity misdemeanor” — the names of the students quoted have been withheld.

“It’s about overcoming societal norms. And not to be rebellious, but to show people that they don’t need to be scared of them . . . I don’t feel very rebellious. I just feel like I’m showing people you can be different and just do stuff like this that you would be scared of doing, and you can show who you are, like your full self — even your most private parts — and not be ashamed.”

“Everyone should appreciate their body, and everyone else’s body, because no matter the size and shape, or hairiness, or non-hairiness, or color, it’s always beautiful.”

Some of these adventurous students have a less profound message.

“I streak because I want to show the women of UNC what God blessed this campus with, and that’s my genitalia. Everyone should see it, why not; I’m proud. I’m proud of my nuts. These are Tar Heel nuts. They’re Tar Heel bred — Tar nuts — and when they die, my nuts will be Tar Heel dead.”

Streaking through the libraries on the first day of exams: it's a notorious UNC tradition. What do you think?

Reyna Desai is a freelancer for the Reese Felts Digital News Project.

  1. why did you edit the nudity out? cool idea though its a fun video

    Comment by @Rhetoricjams on December 15, 2010 at 8:11 pm

  2. these people are totally NOT the ul streakers. the ***real*** ul streakers streak ***only*** through the ul at (or sometimes slightly before) midnight. they do not streak through davis or the union. while this other group of streakers certainly show off a lot more, they've only been doing it for the past year or two. sure, they're participating in the tradition, but i would like to point out that what they do is NOT streaking. streaking involves moving quickly through a public space while naked.
    the people who are featured in this article/video hang out and dance around and sing songs and are, quite simply, exhibitionists.

    Comment by a real ul streaker. on December 16, 2010 at 12:43 am

  3. Defending the societal norms under attack by these hooligans.

    You think you're going to show all these people your disgusting body?

    We'll show you who /really/ controls your body.

    Comment by Jon on December 16, 2010 at 8:22 am

  4. Here, ladies and gentlemen is the ultimate hipster comment. A streaker, who feels offended by the fact that another 'rival' group of streakers is co opting their own 'tradition' of running naked around through the library. In what way does this group of streakers hamper your ability to do the same thing?

    Are you mad because you see this group as destroying the tradition of streaking "***only*** through the UL". Or is that you're pissed off because you were out-hipstered by a group of rival hipsters.

    Comment by LOL@HIPSTERS on December 16, 2010 at 9:13 pm
